choices.text: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation:  

 

The spirometry graph compares a normal patient's lung function with that of the patient. The normal graph shows an FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) of more than 70%, which is typical in healthy individuals. In contrast, the patient's graph shows a significantly reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of approximately 50-55%, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

 

Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced airflow due to airway narrowing or obstruction, leading to a lower FEV1/FVC ratio. The common obstructive lung diseases include asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, COPD, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: This typically causes restrictive lung disease, not obstructive, and would present with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio but reduced lung volumes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is an interstitial lung disease, which is restrictive. It would show a normal or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced lung volumes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Another interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive patterns on spirometry, characterized by a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced total lung capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is indicative of obstructive lung disease. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the obstructive lung disease associated with this spirometry pattern.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps


Lim's forceps are designed for ophthalmic procedures as well. They are used to hold and stabilize the eye during surgery, particularly during corneal suturing. They have a platform-like, non-toothed tip to hold the delicate eye tissue without causing damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McPherson forceps: McPherson forceps are typically very delicate instruments used in ophthalmic surgery, especially in procedures involving the cornea and the lens, such as cataract surgery. They have very fine tips for precise manipulation of delicate eye tissues.

 

Option C. Artery forceps: Artery forceps, also known as hemostats, are used in various types of surgeries to grasp and clamp blood vessels to prevent bleeding. They are usually not used in ophthalmic surgeries due to their size and the nature of their design, which is intended to handle larger structures than those found within the eye.

 

Option D. SR (Suture Removal) holding forceps: SR holding forceps are designed for the removal of sutures. They have a small, notched tip at one end to grab and hold the suture for easier removal. They are generally not delicate enough for holding eye tissues during ophthalmic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lim’s forceps are specialized ophthalmic instruments used primarily for corneal suturing, featuring a platform-like tip to gently hold eye tissues during delicate procedures.

questions.text: What is the best contrast agent for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Barium contrast is contraindicated in esophageal perforation as it causes mediastinitis.

 

Iodinated contrast is safe for suspected GI perforation or trachea-esophageal fistula where barium is contraindicated. Iohexol (low osmolar) is preferred over Gastrograffin (high-osmolar) as it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrograffin: While also iodine-based and water-soluble, Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar contrast agent that can be riskier in cases of perforation due to the potential for causing severe pulmonary complications if aspirated.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is primarily used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and is not suitable for gastrointestinal tract imaging, especially in the context of suspected perforations.

 

Option D. Barium sulphate: Although providing high-quality imaging, barium sulphate is contraindicated in cases of suspected perforations due to its potential to cause severe inflammatory reactions if it escapes into the mediastinal or pleural spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth
Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease

questions.text: Which of the following is false about von Willebrand disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and is classified into three main types: Type I, Type II, and Type III.

 

  • Type I vWD is the most common form and is characterized by a mild reduction in the quantity of von Willebrand factor (vWF). It typically presents with mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding rather than severe bleeding from birth, making option A false.
  • Type II vWD involves a qualitative defect of vWF, leading to reduced activity rather than quantity, and presents with moderate bleeding tendencies.
  • Type III vWD is the most severe form, with very low levels or complete absence of vWF, leading to severe bleeding symptoms. This type is rare but clinically severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor: This statement is true as Type II vWD is characterized by a functional defect in the von Willebrand factor, affecting its activity rather than the amount.

 

Option C. Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor: This is correct; Type III vWD is associated with very low or absent levels of vWF, causing severe bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease: This is true. Due to extremely low levels of vWF, Type III vWD is associated with severe clinical manifestations, including spontaneous bleeding episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I von Willebrand disease presents with mild to moderate bleeding and is the least severe form, contrasting with Type III, which has very low vWF levels and presents as a severe disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

 

Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it's high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Screening Tests for UTI:

 

Option B. Griess Nitrite test: This test detects nitrites in the urine, which are generally produced by nitrate-reducing bacteria such as Escherichia coli, a common cause of UTIs. It is a quick and effective screening tool.

 

Option C. Leukocyte esterase test: This test identifies the presence of leukocyte esterase, an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes). A positive result suggests inflammation or infection, common in UTIs.

 

Option D. Wet mount examination: This involves examining a sample of urine under a microscope to detect the presence of pus cells, bacteria, or other elements indicative of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

 

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

 

Quantitative Culture:

 

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatigability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12 - 14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very less fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9gm/dl and MCV 120 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid deficiency

 

The given laboratory values showing anemia and increased MC are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia.

 

This could be due to a lack of cyanocobalamin or folic acid. The lack of fruits and vegetables in the past suggests folic acid deficiency. (folic acid word derived from foliage-green leafy vegetables)

 

Animal products such as meat, fish, milk, and eggs are good sources of vitamin B12.

 

Green vegetables like lettuce, spinach, asparagus, and broccoli are high in folic acid.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, peripheral blood examination reveals oval macrocytes with anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. MCV is typically greater than 100 fL. (normal value: 80-100 fL). The MCHC is not elevated because most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and appear hyperchromic. The number of reticulocytes is low. Neutrophils are larger than normal and have five or more nuclear lobules, indicating nuclear hyper segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanocobalamin deficiency: Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the dietary history here suggests folic acid deficiency as the primary cause, given the lack of fruits and vegetables.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia, not macrocytic anemia as indicated by the elevated MCV.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the presence of spherocytes (spherical red blood cells) and usually presents with a normal or slightly decreased MCV, not the significantly elevated MCV seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of anemia in this patient, given the elevated MCV and dietary habits lacking in fruits and vegetables, is folic acid deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia due to folic acid deficiency presents with macrocytic red blood cells and can be confirmed by dietary history and characteristic blood smear findings.

questions.text: In a partogram, the progression of labor is charted with respect to which of the following? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical dilatation

 

The partogram (also called partograph) is a graphic representation of labor progress where cervical dilatation is plotted against time. The graph shows cervical dilatation measured in centimeters plotted as "X" marks against time in hours. This creates the primary curve that demonstrates the progression of labor. The partogram divides labor into latent phase and active phase, with the active phase starting at 5 cm dilatation according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal Heart Rate: is incorrect because while fetal heart rate is recorded on the partogram, it is not the parameter used to chart the progression of labor. FHR is monitored and recorded to assess fetal wellbeing during labor.

 

Option C. Maternal BP: is incorrect because maternal blood pressure is monitored and recorded on the partogram for maternal safety, but it does not reflect the progression of labor.

 

Option D. Cervical length: is incorrect because although cervical length is related to labor progress (through effacement), it is cervical dilatation, not length, that is specifically plotted to track labor progression on the partogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The partogram tracks labor progression primarily through plotting cervical dilatation against time, allowing visualization of the labor curve and early identification of deviation from normal labor patterns. This graphic tool is essential for timely decisions regarding labor management.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: A 5-year-old came with complaints of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains. On further examination, petechie are seen. What is the best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

The symptoms described, including swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae, are consistent with scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to impaired wound healing, weakened blood vessels, and bleeding gums.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness and xerophthalmia but is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, bone pains, or petechiae. Vitamin A deficiency is more commonly linked with ocular manifestations and immune system impairment.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, characterized by bone pain and deformities. However, swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, and petechiae are not typical symptoms of Vitamin D deficiency. Furthermore, bone pains in rickets are usually associated with skeletal deformities rather than generalized bone pain.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency can lead to impaired blood clotting, resulting in excessive bleeding. While Vitamin K deficiency can cause petechiae due to bleeding disorders, it is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, or bone pains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae in a child are characteristic of scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

questions.text: Oculus Dexter refers to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Eye

 

Oculus Dexter (OD) is the Latin medical term used to specifically designate the right eye in ophthalmological documentation. This terminology is part of the standard nomenclature in ophthalmic practice and is used in prescriptions, medical records, and clinical communications. The counterpart term for the left eye is Oculus Sinister (OS), while Oculus Uterque (OU) refers to both eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Eye: This is incorrect as left eye is designated as Oculus Sinister (OS), not Oculus Dexter. This is a fundamental distinction in ophthalmic terminology that prevents confusion in patient management.

 

Option C. Both Eyes: This is incorrect because both eyes are referred to as Oculus Uterque (OU). Oculus Dexter specifically refers to only the right eye, not both eyes simultaneously.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because Oculus Dexter does indeed have a specific meaning in ophthalmic terminology, which is the right eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculus Dexter (OD) refers specifically to the right eye in ophthalmological terminology, forming part of the essential Latin abbreviations used in clinical documentation alongside OS (left eye) and OU (both eyes).

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

choices.text: 73 degree Celsius for 20 minutes
63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes
72 degree Celsius for 30 seconds
63 degree Celsius for 30 seconds

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes

 

Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either

 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15-20 seconds: the flash process

 

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pasteurization can be conducted using different time-temperature combinations, primarily the Holder method (63°C for 30 minutes) and the flash pasteurization method (72°C for 15-20 seconds), each designed to ensure the safety of milk consumption while preserving its quality.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes conjunctival xerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to a condition called xerophthalmia, which causes conjunctival xerosis, also known as dry eye. Xerophthalmia can be classified into two types: primary and secondary.

 

Primary xerophthalmia has five categories:

 

  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis (dry eye)
  • X1B: Bitot's spots (a specific manifestation)
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration
  • X3B: Keratomalacia

 

Secondary manifestations of xerophthalmia include:

 

  • XN: Night blindness
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus
  • XS: Xerophthalmic scarring

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "4 D's" (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death). It does not directly cause conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in developing fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia, which leads to conjunctival xerosis (dry eye) and other ocular manifestations, including Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, corneal ulceration, and keratomalacia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with stable vitals and ECG showing PSVT. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

     

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in a stable child begins with pharmacological intervention rather than immediate cardioversion. Adenosine is the drug of choice for PSVT due to its ability to temporarily block the atrioventricular node, effectively terminating the arrhythmia.

 

The initial dose of adenosine recommended is 0.1 mg/kg given as a rapid IV bolus over 1-3 seconds. If there is no response, subsequent doses can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg, and if necessary, 0.3 mg/kg can be administered under monitored conditions. Rapid bolus administration is essential, followed by a 5-10 ml of saline flush to ensure the drug reaches systemic circulation quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardioversion: Cardioversion is typically reserved for cases where the patient is unstable or when pharmacological management fails. In a stable patient, the initial approach is to use adenosine to terminate the PSVT without the need for electrical intervention.

 

Option B. Adenosine 0.3 mg per kg: While this dosage of adenosine can be used if initial doses do not work, it is not the starting dose. The initial dose should be lower, at 0.1 mg/kg, to minimize potential adverse effects.

 

Option C. Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg: This dose of adenosine is appropriate for a second attempt if the initial dose (0.1 mg/kg) does not resolve the PSVT. It is not the first-line dose but can be escalated to after the initial dose fails.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable PSVT in children, adenosine is the first-line treatment, starting at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg. If this dose is ineffective, the dose may be escalated in subsequent attempts.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Supraphysiological doses of Vitamin B3, also known as Niacin, have been known to cause adverse effects, including macular edema and macular cysts. This side effect is relatively rare but has been documented in some cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to various eye problems, but it is not associated with macular edema and macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is essential for various bodily functions, including bone health, but it is not known to cause macular edema or macular cysts.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage, but it is not associated with macular edema or macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)

 

Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.

 

Other symptoms –

 

  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

 

The clinical scenario of an unstable patient and the given X-ray findings, which showing hyperlucent right hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift is suggestive of a tension pneumothorax. Inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line followed by a chest tube in the triangle of safety is the best course of action for the management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Pericardiocentesis: This is performed in cases of cardiac tamponade (when presents with beck’s triad), where there is fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, not applicable here as the X-ray does not suggest this condition.

 

Option. B. Thoracotomy: Indicated for more complex chest injuries or when less invasive procedures fail to resolve the issue. It's a more invasive approach typically reserved for critical cases not resolved by needle thoracostomy or chest tube insertion.

 

Option. D. Chest tube insertion: While ultimately necessary for ongoing management and air evacuation, initial needle thoracostomy is critical to quickly relieve the pressure due to its speed and efficacy in an emergency setting. Chemical pleurodesis, which involves inhaling talc into the chest cavity, is used to achieve pleural adhesion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, and excessive hair growth (hirsutism). What is the initial treatment of choice? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lifestyle measures

 

In PCOS management, lifestyle modifications are always the first-line approach before initiating any pharmacological treatment. patients should be counseled for lifestyle measures for at least 6 months before starting any medications. This includes focus on improving BMI through diet and exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Metformin: While metformin can be used in PCOS management, particularly for insulin resistance, it is not the first-line treatment. It is considered after lifestyle modifications have been attempted.

 

Option B. Combined OCPs: Though OCPs are effective in managing PCOS symptoms like irregular periods and hyperandrogenism, they are typically started only if lifestyle modifications fail to show improvement after 6 months.

 

Option C. Clomiphene citrate: This is used specifically for ovulation induction in PCOS patients seeking fertility. It is not the first-line treatment for general PCOS management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise) are the first-line treatment for PCOS, to be tried for 6 months before considering pharmacological options.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klinefelter's Syndrome

 

Klinefelter's Syndrome is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening. Standard prenatal screening protocols primarily target trisomies 21, 18, and 13, as well as Turner's syndrome. The highly effective first trimester combined screening (nuchal translucency with serum markers β-hCG and PAPP-A) and cell-free DNA testing are designed to detect these specific conditions. Klinefelter's Syndrome (47, XXY) is not prominently featured in the standard screening algorithms discussed in prenatal care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome): This is actually the most commonly screened aneuploidy. The detection rate is extremely high - 99% with cell-free DNA testing and 85-92% with combined first trimester screening. First trimester screening shows increased β-hCG, decreased PAPP-A, and increased nuchal translucency in Down syndrome

.

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards' syndrome): This is specifically included in standard screening protocols. It presents with decreased β-hCG and decreased PAPP-A in first trimester screening, with a high detection rate using combined screening approaches.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome (Monosomy X): This is reliably detected through nuchal thickness screening. Monosomy X (45,XO) is the "single most frequent specific chromosomal anomaly" comprising 9-13% of chromosomal abnormalities detected in spontaneous abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While prenatal screening programs effectively detect the common trisomies (21, 18, 13) and Turner syndrome through combined approaches, Klinefelter's Syndrome is less emphasized in standard screening protocols, making it more likely to be missed in routine prenatal screening.

questions.text: During which week of embryonic development does cardiac activity typically commence? (NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4th week

 

By the fourth week, the early heart begins to form and starts its contractions. The heart develops from a simple linear tube into a looping structure during this time. This looping eventually gives rise to the various chambers of the heart. Towards the end of the 4th week, the heart starts to beat and pump blood. However, it's worth noting that while the heart starts to beat during this week, the full structure of the heart with its four chambers isn't fully developed yet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd week: During the second week of embryonic development, formation of the bilaminar embryonic disc takes place, which consists of the epiblast and hypoblast. Additionally, events like the formation of the amniotic cavity, yolk sac and gastrulation begins towards the end of this week. At this point, the heart has not yet begun to form, and thus, there's no heart beating during the 2nd week.

 

Option C. 6th week: By the sixth week, the heart's development has progressed further. The interatrial and interventricular septa are beginning to form. While the heart is beating and becoming more sophisticated in its function, it had already started its contractions in the 4th week.

 

Option D. 10th week: By the 10th week, the embryonic period is concluding, and the fetal period is about to commence. The heart is much more developed, with more defined chambers and valves. Most major organs and external structures are formed by this time, and the fetus looks unmistakably human.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by:  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

 

Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.

 

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules. The most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli

 

Various clinical forms of actinomycosis include cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

 

Among them, actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nocardia: Incorrect, although Nocardia can also cause cutaneous infections with abscess and sinus formation, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, known primarily for causing gastrointestinal infections rather than chronic skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option D. Tularemia: Incorrect, although it can cause ulceroglandular disease with skin ulcers and lymphadenopathy, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma accuminata

 

  • Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).
  • The main causative agent is HPV-6 and 11.
  • Lesions: Typically, they grow in clusters along a narrow stalk giving it a cauliflower appearance but at times the stalk may be broad and thick
  • Treatment: Cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision or topical use of 5-fluorouracil, trichloro-acetic acid or intralesional interferon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum:

 

  • Caused by a pox virus transmitted by body contact or towels or clothing.
  • It is commonly seen in immunodeficient subject or with HIV infections.
  • The lesions vary in size up to 1 cm, dome shaped, pearly-white in colour and often umbilicated.
  • They are usually multiple and can occur anywhere in the skin and genitalia.
  • Microscopic appearance reveals numerous inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies) in the cytoplasm of the cells with Giemsa stain.
  • Treatment: 
    • Evacuation of caseous material from the nodule under local anaesthetic is done.
    • The floor of the nodule is then treated chemically with ferric sub-sulphate or trichloroacetic acid (85%) solution.
    • Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is applied until a halo of ice is formed around the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

 

 

Option D. Herpes:

 

  • The causative organism is herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2.
  • It is usually transmitted sexually by an infected partner/ oro-genital contact.
  • The incubation period is 2–14 days.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Initially, red painful inflammatory areas appear commonly on the clitoris, labia, vestibule, vagina, perineum, and cervix.
    • Multiple vesicles appear which progress into multiple shallow ulcers and ultimately heal up spontaneously by crusting.
    • It takes about 3 weeks to complete the process.
    • Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever, malaise, and headache.
    •  There may be vulvar burning, pruritus, dysuria, or retention of urine.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are characterized by multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, caused by HPV-6 and 11, and treated with cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical agents.

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

 

Given the age of the patient and the presence of both right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is Nasopharyngeal cancer.

 

Nasopharyngeal cancer can present with serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor or swollen lymph nodes in the nasopharyngeal region. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a common finding due to the spread of the malignancy to the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiofibroma, specifically juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. It can cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds), but is less commonly associated with serous otitis media and is not typically diagnosed in a 50-year-old male.

 

Option C. Adenoid hypertrophy is more common in children and can cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media; however, it is unlikely to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in adults.

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion, also known as serous otitis media, is the accumulation of fluid within the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction, which could be secondary to a mass effect from a nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.
